==What to Check For==
Verify that Automatic Reference Counting is used.
==Why==
Using Automatic Reference Counting prevents use-after-free vulnerabilities.
==How to Check==
To verify that Automatic Reference Counting(ARC) is used:
# **Identify the SDK version.** Automatic Reference Counting is only available in iOS SDK versions 5.0 and higher. If the SDK version is lower than that, then ARC is not being used. # **Check XCode settings.** Examine XCode compiler options. Make sure that //Objective-C Automatic Reference Counting// is set to //yes//. # **(Optional) Examine the binary.** Use the //otool// command to detect if ARC symbols are present in a binary, like so:\\{{{ otool -I -v BinaryFile }}}\\ Examine the output of the //otool// command. The presence of at least some of the following symbols means that ARC is being used by the binary: #* //_objc_release #* //_obc_retain #* //_objc_storeStrong #* //_objc_retainAutoreleaseReturnValue #* //_objc_autoreleaseReturnValue//\\
==How to Fix==
To enable Automatic Reference Counting(ARC):
# **Use a compatible SDK.** Use iOS SDK 5.0 or higher to be able to use Automatic Reference Counting. # **Launch XCode.** Open the XCode environment. # **Enable Automatic Reference Counting.** Set the compiler option //Objective-C Automatic Reference Counting// to //yes//.
